headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Contamination Fears in Ohio; Two Women Saved from Rubble; Santos Wrote Back Checks for Puppies. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: JASON CARROLL, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Popping up in these creeks. So much distrust here on the ground. This after residents were told it was OK to go home. And then only to be told their water may not be safe.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) DR. BRUCE VANDERHOOF, DIRECTOR, OHIO DEPT. OF HEALTH: We are strongly recommending those who have not yet had their water source checked to use bottled water, and bottled water is being made available. CARROLL (voice over): More than a week after a toxic train derailment that led to the evacuation of much of this small Ohio town, state health officials are urging some East Palestine residence to drink bottled water until water tests are complete.

utterances.speaker: VANDERHOOF
utterances.sentences: This is going to be particularly important if you are pregnant, if you are breast-feeding or if you are preparing formula for an infant.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Officials say the toxic spill was largely contained the day after the derailment and that tests have shown the air quality is safe. But they have found low levels of contaminants in four nearby waterways spanning seven and a half miles, including Leslie Run, a creek which runs through East Palestine, and neighboring Negley, right through the back of Cathy Reese's property.CARROLL (on camera): In the back of your property back here they found dead fish?

utterances.speaker: CATHY REESE, NEGLEY RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, they saw dead fish.CARROLL (voice over): Reese says she has been drinking bottled water instead of well water ever since she started spotting dead fish in the creek following the derailment. She says she's still waiting for the state to come and test her well water.

utterances.speaker: REESE
utterances.sentences: Air wise, I feel OK. Water wise, no, I'm - no. There's just too many chemicals and stuff that were spilled that they still don't want to identify completely.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: An Ohio Department of Natural Resources official estimates sometimes 3,500 fish in the state have died following the train derailment.These people saw the flames from their homes and worried their neighborhood still may not be safe. CARROLL (on camera): What about testing water or ground?

utterances.speaker: JIM STEWART, EAST PALESTINE RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Nothing yet.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: STEWART
utterances.sentences: And like I said, I don't recommend you put anything in the ground. I mean, vegetables or tomatoes or anything this year because we don't know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't think they're going to do enough.CARROLL (voice over): And some residents say they have been frustrated by what they describe as a lack of communication with officials on the ground.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We pass all of the creeks and there's crew after crew with white hoses and black hoses all through the creeks. They're not telling us why. And this is - this is daily. I'm driving my children to school past all of this and they're asking me questions that I don't have answers to.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: Some of their questions, unanswered. We found getting information just as challenging.CARROLL (on camera): Can you tell me, are they pumping water out or are you pumping water back in?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You have to talk to the guys at the top of the hill, sir. We're - we're just grunts.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: We're just trying to get a sense of what - what those pumps are. Can you just - someone just --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Norfolk Southern can tell you everything. That's the hotline. They can tell you everything.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: You realize people are calling this number and no one is getting back to them.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That -- we're just told to direct people to that number.CARROLL (voice over): The governor asked by reporters Tuesday if he would feel comfortable living in East Palestine. GOV. MIKE DEWINE (R-OH): Look, I think that I would be drinking the bottled water and I would be continuing to find out what the tests were showing as far as the air. I would be alert and concerned. But I think I would probably be back in my house.

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: But residents like Cathy Reese say they are left with few choices.

utterances.speaker: REESE
utterances.sentences: Just, I guess, pray and keep drinking bottled water until we know for sure what's going on.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: CARROLL
utterances.sentences: The governor also indicated that the train that was traveling through here from Norfolk Southern was not actually classified as a hazardous materials train and, therefore, the railroad company, Norfolk Southern, again, did not have to notify anyone in the state that it was coming through the state. The governor saying that that is something that's got to change and he's going to be talking to Congress about it.Don.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, after seeing those fish that you just reported on, I mean how could anyone trust that, you know, everything is OK there, Jason? Thank you. Lots of answers to come. Lots of questions and lots of answers to come, we hope.And in our 8:00 hour, we're going to speak with Ohio Governor Mike DeWine about - you saw him there in Jason's story - about these growing environmental and health concerns.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Ahead, we have CNN crews live on the ground in Turkey as we are getting a close-up look and an overhead look at the devastation and the rescue efforts that are still very much underway more than a week after that devastating earthquake.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Even though there's over 100,000 rescuers, they would need a million. And this is just one city.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Just an incredible look there from Jomana.You're also going to want to stick around for this. Our own Dr. Sanjay Gupta is on the ground in Turkey. In the next hour, he is going to take us inside one of the top trauma hospitals, how they're dealing with the fallout near the earthquake zone.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And back here in the U.S., another day, another allegation against Congressman George Santos. This time an Amish farmer says he was duped.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GARY TUCHMAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: You thought they pulled a fast one on you?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: There are new revelations about embattled Republican Congressman George Santos this morning. An Amish farmer in Pennsylvania claims Santos wrote a bad check for purebred puppies. It was five years ago. CNN has confirmed Santos was charged with theft in York County after nine bad checks with his name on them went to Amish dog breeders in the area.CNN's Gary Tuchman has the story now. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) GARY TUCHMAN, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice over): We've told this Amish dairy farmer in Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, we'll protect his identity. As this father of ten, who we will call Fred, tells us the story of a man who came to his house a little over five years ago to buy puppies that Fred breeds as a side job. "FRED," AMISH FARMER: He seemed uncomfortable and nervous and fidgety. So, that's when I started getting suspicious.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: His instincts were correct. These are nine checks from November 2017. The name on each of them, George Santos. The checks to buy puppies, obtained by CNN, were written to Fred and other Amish dog breeders. They totaled more than $15,000.Fred says the man, he then simply knew as George, came with a female assistant, and they cut their deal in this very room we're standing in, the milk house. He says the man wanted two German shepherds.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: He says, OK, we're going to take that puppy and that puppy. And his assistant grabs the two puppies, takes them out the door and he pulls out a check. I was like, oh, no, is this guy going to pay me with a check? But then I was very suspicious.TUCHMAN (on camera): Because she -- you told me before, she put the dogs in the car, correct?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Before they paid for them?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: So, you're suspicious because he's going to pay with a check, and you don't take checks.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: Right. And I told him, I don't take checks. All I can take is cash. Well, he said, would you expect me to carry enough cash to buy a bunch of puppies on a trip like this? I do not have cash. The only thing I can give you is a check. Well, I thought to myself, it looks like I'm done.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: You're stuck?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: I'm stuck.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Because the dogs are already in the car.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: The dogs are in the car.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: You thought they pulled a fast one on you.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: Right. And it was obvious to me by that time they probably pulled a fast one on me.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: So you said, through the goodness of your heart, I take it, that you'll take the check?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: I said, I've decided a check is better than nothing, I'll give it a try.TUCHMAN (voice over): And the results of that try.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: (on camera)

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: The check bounced, right.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And then you were charged a fee, too, for -

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: A minimum -

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Depositing a bounced check.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Have you gotten the money back?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Have you heard from anybody about it?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Santos.TUCHMAN (voice over): Just three days after all these puppies were purchased, Santos participated in an adoption event at a pet supply store in Staten Island, New York, according to a former owner of the business. That man, Daniel Avissato, tells CNN he wrote a check for a few hundred dollars to Santos' pet rescue charity following the event, but says he later saw his check online and that someone crossed out the charity name and wrote Anthony Devolder, another name that Santos has used.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The New York Republicans are calling you a disgrace.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: We've received no comment from Santos or his attorney regarding all this.Santos was ultimately charged with theft by Pennsylvania authorities. But the charge was later dropped after Santos made a claim that somebody had stolen his checkbook, according to a lawyer who is a former friend of his. That lawyer, Tiffany Bogosian, says she no longer believes him.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY BOGOSIAN, FORMER FRIEND OF SANTOS
utterances.sentences: He's definitely, you know, not qualified to be where he is in Congress. And he should really be in jail.TUCHMAN (on camera): This is George Santos.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Do you believe this is the man who bought your dogs and put them in the car and took them away from you?

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: I feel it is, based on my memory, I would say, yes, it is.TUCHMAN (voice over): Fred loves dogs. He has his own and still breeds others. He's tried his best to forget about being fleeced. But Santos' ascension to Congress has made forgetting impossible.

utterances.speaker: FRED
utterances.sentences: I'm disappointed that a person like that would have a chance to get into the House of Representatives.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Now, Fred tells me he used to think things like this only happened in the outside world. But today he is aware they happen in his world too.Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You know, Gary, you've been doing this for a long time. And I -- there is story after story after story for George Santos. And I just wonder -- good to see you, by the way.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: It's nice seeing you too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I just wonder if -- do you - do you - do you think that all of these stories and allegations kind of cancel each other out where people are just like, well, you know, that may be a concern for people who may have some legitimate issues with George Santos?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, my reaction was, you cannot make this up. Now, it's like Amish dog breeders? Like, it's just like the line is -- where is it?

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: I hope people think I did not make it up.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You didn't.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: This all happened.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You did not make it up. It was a great report.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Gary Tuchman, so nice to have you on set.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Nice seeing you, Kaitlan. Nice seeing you, Don.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Thanks.All right, also this morning, a meltdown and that historic grounding and planes almost colliding twice. What is happening in the aviation industry? What the FAA is doing about it. What their response is. We'll tell you next. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The long awaited mystery is now over. The name of the person who is the only player to match all six numbers of the historic Powerball drawing last November is Edwin Castro.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Not Kaitlan Collins.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow. Not Don Lemon.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, my - no, I'll - I - I'd love to have that problem.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. A lot of problems.
